title: Electric flux curved and flat surfaces A1 and A2

content.description: A point charge <math alttext="q" overflow="scroll"><mi>q</mi></math> is located at the origin of a coordinate system, as shown. Above the point charge are two surfaces, one curved and one flat. The curved surface has area <math alttext="A, sub 1 equals, 0.40 meter squared" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>A</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0.40</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><msup><mtext> m</mtext><mn>2</mn></msup></math> and is a portion of a sphere of radius <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math> that is centered at the origin. The flat surface is a circle of area <math alttext="A, sub 2 equals, 0.30 meter squared" overflow="scroll"> <msub> <mi>A</mi> <mn>2</mn> </msub> <mo>=</mo> <mn>0.30</mn> <mspace width="0.2em"> </mspace> <msup> <mtext> m</mtext> <mn>2</mn> </msup> </math>. The two surfaces share the same circular border. The electric field at all points on the curved surface has magnitude <math alttext="E sub 1 equals, 2.0 newtons per coulomb" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>2.0</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext> N</mtext><mo>/</mo><mtext>C</mtext></math> and is directed away from the point charge. The electric field at the center of the flat surface has magnitude <math alttext="E sub 2 equals, 8.0 newtons per coulomb" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>8.0</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext> N</mtext><mo>/</mo><mtext>C</mtext></math> and is also directed away from the point charge.
content.question: What is the electric flux through the flat surface of area <math alttext="A, sub 2" overflow="scroll"> <msub> <mi>A</mi> <mn>2</mn> </msub> </math>?
